page.title: 01South west Longmynd, Shrops
page.content: The bracken and heather covered top of the Longmynd is a wild desolate area. The Portway, an ancient pack horse route follows the ridge. Streams emerge from the peaty springs and flow away down the steep sided valleys, called hollowsand batches, like Ashes Hollow. The area, popular in summer with walkers and picnickers, provides interest for ornithologists and stream dipping students. Near the southern end of the Longmynd is one of the first gliding airfields, established in 1934 by the Midland Gliding Club which today is among the country's largest clubs. Facilities include residential clubhouse, workshops and hangar for its glider fleet. The club operates some 300 days a year provi- ding glider launching by aeroplane, winch or traditional catapult & flying training for its 250 members.
